title: From John O'Groats to Land's End; Or, 1372 miles on foot; A book of days and chronicle of adventures by two pedestrians on tour
author: Naylor, John Anderton
snippet: The following concise account of the career ofthis beautiful but unfortunate Queen and her son King James greatlyinterested us. She was born at Linlithgow Palace in the year 1542, andher father died when she was only eight days old. In the next year shewas crowned Queen of Scotland at Stirling, and remained at the Castlethere for about four years.

title: Scotland, its faith and its features; or, a Visit to Blair Athol
author: Trench, Francis.
snippet: To Edinburgh. — We passedto-day many handsome country-houses andmuch highly cultivated ground * but with theexception of Linlithgow Palace, which wecarefully examined, there was nothing whichcalled my note-book into use. That abode ofroyalty in former times; that " excelling"abode,to use the words of the song in its praise, is, fora ruin, by no means in bad order for restoration,if desired.

title: Seeing Europe with Famous Authors, Volume 2; Great Britain and Ireland, Part 2
author: Francis W. Halsey
snippet: The situation of Linlithgow Palace is eminently beautiful. It stands ona promontory of some elevation, which advances almost into the midst ofthe lake.

title: Seeing Europe with Famous Authors, Volume 2; Great Britain and Ireland, Part 2
author: Francis W. Halsey
snippet: There were two main entrances to Linlithgow Palace. That from the southascends rather steeply from the town, and passes through a strikingGothic archway, flanked by two round towers.

title: Seeing Europe with Famous Authors, Volume 2; Great Britain and Ireland, Part 2
author: Francis W. Halsey
snippet: James IV., a splendid gallant, seems to have founded the mostmagnificent part of Linlithgow Palace; together with the noble entrancebetwixt two flanking towers bearing, on rich entablatures, the royalarms of Scotland, with the collars of the Orders of the Thistle, Garter,and Saint Michael. James IV.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Linlithgow Palace is a massive quadrangular edifice, situated upon an eminence which slopes into the lake. It occupies about an acre of gi-ound, and, though in ruins, is still a beautiful and pictm-esque object.

title: From the Thames to the Trosachs.
author: Thompson, E. H.
snippet: Linlithgow Palace is, by general consent, the finest ruin of its kind in Scotland. Heavy but effective, the somber walls rise above the green knolls of the promontory which divides the lake into two nearly equal portions.

title: Old diaries, 1881-1901 /
author: Gower, Ronald Sutherland
snippet: I shall have it reproduced in my life of the artist, and then present it to ourNational Portrait Gallery. That afternoon, the 21st, I made another little pilgrimage with Mr Napier to Linlithgow Palace ; we carefullyvisited that fine old ruin, and the church near it. I wasstruck by the magnificence of that old palace, which givesone a far greater idea of the stately lives of the StuartKings than does gloomy Holyrood.

title: Miscellaneous Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott, Bart
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: The ruins alone remain to show itsformer splendour. The situation of Linlithgow Palace is eminentlybeautiful. It stands on a promontory of some elevation, which advances almost into the midst ofthe lake.

snippet: The principal entrance is from the east side of the house,through a porch copied from one in Linlithgow Palace. Itis adorned with petrified stags' horns.
